subject: Packaging: remove bashism
commitMessage:
Packaging: remove bashism

Remove bashism in spec files in order to generate bashism free recipes
for the Yocto build. This is necessary to build packages on system
which don't use bash compliant shells (sh, dash...).

Bug-Tizen: BTY-21
Change-Id: I00af48a0e034504aa656e6b5cad6abe63df97e98
Signed-off-by: Kévin THIERRY <kevin.thierry@open.eurogiciel.org>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

I think I removed all the bashism but let's wait for it to be tested by a Yocto build before merging this change (see https://bugs.tizen.org/jira/browse/TC-1964 for the whole discussion).

Patch Set 1:

GBS build succeeded and I checked the changes made in that patch, they are the only bashism.

subject: Revert "Fix build for ARM arch"
commitMessage:
Revert "Fix build for ARM arch"

This reverts commit 9c709a2a93e76d9fdc3008109c2e8ffc976019eb.

Since now problems with qemu-accel and binutils are resolved, the
workaround can be reverted and LTO build can be enabled.

Change-Id: Ib4bdae8994a211dda5911b1509af9c1d904db68a
Signed-off-by: Ilya Palachev <i.palachev@samsung.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1 Verified+1

The issue XWALK-3033 (see https://crosswalk-project.org/jira/browse/XWALK-3033) was resolved with the following changes:

binutils: https://review.tizen.org/gerrit/#/c/31719/
qemu-accel: https://review.tizen.org/gerrit/#/c/31718/
project config: https://review.tizen.org/gerrit/#/c/32202/
qemu: https://review.tizen.org/gerrit/#/c/31782/
qemu: https://review.tizen.org/gerrit/#/c/32365/
crosswalk: https://review.tizen.org/gerrit/#/c/32370/

Details about these changes can be found in their commit messages.

All these 6 changes should be submitted in one request (they require each other).

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1 Verified+1

Verified at
https://build.tizen.org/package/show?package=crosswalk&project=devel:arm_toolchain:Mobile:Tizen_Common

subject: XMLHttpRequest.responseURL should exclude url fragment
commitMessage:
XMLHttpRequest.responseURL should exclude url fragment

According to the specification of responseURL, it will return empty string
if the response URL is null otherwise it will return its serialization with exclude fragment flag set.

Specs : https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/#the-responseurl-attribute

This is a merge of Upstream Patch https://codereview.chromium.org/681513003/.

Change-Id: I0c8947a63961cac19213b66674398ff4deec6ec7
Signed-off-by: Paritosh Kumar <paritosh.in@samsung.com>

comments.message: Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated

subject: Set file capabilities for xwalk binary
commitMessage:
Set file capabilities for xwalk binary

This is part of a solution for setting Smack labels for EP and RP in Tizen.
User sessions will be run with cap_mac_admin and cap_setgid inheritable
capabilities. This will allow user programs to inherit these caps from
executable files. In this patch we are setting those caps for crosswalk
executables, so EP and RP will start with cap_mac_admin and cap_setgid in
effective, permitted and inheritable sets.

Later these programs will call security-manager functions for setting Smack
labels and adding process to groups based on enabled privileges (these
operations require capabilities). Then the capabilities will be dropped.
Final result should be to have EP and RP run with application Smack label
and permitted groups and dropped capabilities.

Change-Id: I93c6b14765a8a6b4ee56dc94f30f82c0448d12d0
Signed-off-by: Rafal Krypa <r.krypa@samsung.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't agree with the way of using capability inheritance.

In the review https://review.tizen.org/gerrit/#/c/27976/, you expect to have inheritable flags to be cap_mac_admin, cap_setgid but you are here setting this capabilities using permitted and inheritable.

The situation have to be cleaner: either use only permitted or use only inheritable. The former being safer because inheritable capabilities are never dropped during execve.

Patch Set 1:

Summary my idea:
- systemd user session, being the place where capabilities are dropped (parent systemd process is privileged), keeps cap_mac_admin and cap_setgid in the inheritable cap set
- all processes spawned in that session will also have the capabilities in inheritable cap set, unless they drop it explicitly (we can also modify systemd services for user to drop the caps, i.e. from dbus user session)
- when xwalk (BP) or xwalk-launch (EP) are launched, file capabiliies (=ei) will mix with process capabilities (=i) to make the caps effective (=epi)
- Crosswalk BP is supposed to run with effective capabilities all the time
- When BP spawns RP, it should call security-manager functions in the new process. The functions will make use of capabilities to set Smack and gids and then drop the capabilities
- Also xwalk-launch should be patched to call security-manager as early as possible
- When something tries to execute xwalk or xwalk-launcher from outside of user session (or from application, which drops the capabilities), they won't get the capabilities due to not having them as inheritable in the process

Patch Set 1:

I made a mistake when reading =ei and thinking =epi. That explains some of my words. Sorry for the trouble.

But I really would like to know what is better to use in tizen?

- inheritable through chain of =i / =ei that should be dropped
or
- setting on need using =pe

So lets argue on it. For me as =pe is always possible for a given executable, there is no need to enforce the chain and no need to drop inheritable capabilities on execve. That is simpler. Is it safer? Not less safer because capabilities on files can still be set.

Patch Set 1:

IMO =ep on a file is less safe, because it enables any process that is able to execute programs to launch it's own privileged crosswalk, with whatever command line or environment arguments. That any process could be an application or an unprivileged non-user program.

However if you feel like discussing this, we will have a perfect opportunity for discussion soon. So if we don' agree at the moment, let's leave it in Gerrit for now.

Patch Set 3:

Rafal, please could you also deliver a patch also into github project?

Patch Set 3:

This change is very Tizen-specific and depends on other patch configuring user session in Tizen (https://review.tizen.org/gerrit/27976). I expected Gerrit on tizen.org to be the proper place to introduce this patch. Am I wrong?

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

Rafal, it is a right place , we have just to take care about the sync with upstream package
Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

I trust you that cap_mac_override is needed but why?

Patch Set 6:

Could you check the version, there is something strange

subject: [Tizen] Move application binary path from .config to TZ_USER_APP / TZ_SYS_RW_APP
commitMessage:
[Tizen] Move application binary path from .config to TZ_USER_APP / TZ_SYS_RW_APP

user application binary is now located in TZ_USER_APP instead of /$HOME/.config
global application binary in TZ_SYS_RW_APP instead of /usr/apps/.config

Bug-Tizen: XWALK-2672
Change-Id: I13f9d2921e8a2b6ceaa9691247ce7c367d53f73d
Signed-off-by: Sabera Djelti (sdi2) <sabera.djelti@open.eurogiciel.org>

comments.message: Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated

The change could not be merged due to a path conflict.

Please rebase the change locally and upload the rebased commit for review.

subject: Get the GPU process launched on Linux Kernel 3.14.20 or 3.14.22
commitMessage:
Get the GPU process launched on Linux Kernel 3.14.20 or 3.14.22

The GPU process does not launch due to the sandbox so it should
be disabled in the GPU process like the browser process.

Bug: https://crosswalk-project.org/jira/browse/XWALK-2789

Change-Id: I9cf340200a1379b601faa978d24795dc6601f7a5

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

While this is a obvious fix for the issue, we need to understand why we can't use the sandboxing for the GPU process anymore. Can you provide that info.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

As Sakari said, we need more data here, and it would be good if this had been submitted to GitHub instead.
This problem reminds me of http://keithp.com/blogs/chromium-dri3/ by the way.

Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> While this is a obvious fix for the issue, we need to understand
 > why we can't use the sandboxing for the GPU process anymore. Can
 > you provide that info.

Sakari, currently oz-wl doesn't work with sandboxing enabled. We always ran with sandboxing disabled.

Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

My patch is a temporary solution. There are other ways to disable the sandbox for the GPU process.

Patch Set 1: -Verified

sorry for noise. not verified. I'm new at this tool

Patch Set 1:

Joone, if you want to disable gpu sandbox, use it;
cmd_line->AppendSwitch(switches::kDisableGpuSandbox)

However, it's very strange. JunghanKim also used --no-sandbox flag in the report; https://github.com/01org/ozone-wayland/issues/284#issuecomment-59147351

Patch Set 1:

ozone-wayland should run with --no-sandbox on Tizen IVI.
It has not tested with the GPU sandbox.

subject: Keep ModelloUI focused after the UI is restored.
commitMessage:
Keep ModelloUI focused after the UI is restored.

When the ModelloUI is restored, this patch allows the UI to get focus
in order to handle touch events without connecting a mouse.

Bug: TC-1763

Change-Id: I2e1d7a3022d12d26a0eb77213147ec6ccac8d99d

subject: VKB does not pop-up when no keyboard is attached.
commitMessage:
VKB does not pop-up when no keyboard is attached.

This patch allows WaylandInputDevice to know focus window in order
to pop-up a virtual keyboard from the active window.

Bug: TC-1810

Change-Id: I9a88e45d0c132fa30b18de676d1bf1f72a322243
